Title: Angels vs.
Overall Purpose: To clarify which type of funder best serves your next move—not just who’s willing to write a cheque.
Why This Matters: Not all money is the same. The wrong investor can distort your rhythm, culture, and direction.
When To Use This Protocol:
When preparing to raise capital
When choosing between angel investors, venture capital, or other funding sources
When assessing whether to accept an unsolicited offer
When wanting to protect strategic direction and cultural integrity

Overall Outcomes.Poor: Funding choice is driven purely by availability → The future risks misaligned expectations and control issues.
Overall Outcomes.Expected: Some fit assessment is done, but major differences in funder expectations remain unaddressed → The future faces occasional conflicts.
Overall Outcomes.Excellent: Funder choice aligns with strategy, culture, and rhythm → The future grows with both capital and integrity intact.
Overall Outcomes.Transcendent: Cultural instinct ensures funding always strengthens, never distorts, the build → The future compounds alignment and momentum.

Themes.Name: Clarifying Strategic Fit
Themes.Purpose of This Theme: To ensure the funder’s goals and vision align with the company’s direction.
Themes.Why This Matters: Even generous funding can cause harm if the funder’s strategy conflicts with yours.

Poor.Present pattern: You accept money without assessing strategic alignment.
Poor.Signals: Funder pushes for pivots misaligned with vision.
Poor.Example moves: Signing term sheets without deep discussion of goals.

Expected.Present pattern: Some alignment check, but not exhaustive.
Expected.Edge condition: You skip asking hard strategic questions.
Expected.Example moves: Discussing vision at high level only.

Excellent.Present pattern: Thorough exploration of funder’s strategic aims.
Excellent.Edge condition: You ensure alignment before accepting funds.

Transcendent.Present pattern: Strategic alignment is non-negotiable cultural instinct.
Transcendent.Signals: Shared language and goals from day one.
Transcendent.Edge condition: You refuse capital that compromises direction.
Transcendent.Example moves: Walking away from high offers with poor fit.
Transcendent.Future effect: Integrity and growth reinforce each other.

Guiding Questions: How does this funder define success?
How does that match our own definition?

Themes.Name: Assessing Cultural Alignment
Themes.Purpose of This Theme: To ensure the funder’s values and working style support the company’s culture.
Themes.Why This Matters: A cultural mismatch can erode trust, morale, and rhythm—regardless of capital provided.

Poor.Present pattern: Culture fit is ignored in funding decisions.
Poor.Signals: Funder imposes work styles that clash with team.
Poor.Edge condition: You see culture as internal only.
Poor.Example moves: Accepting money from aggressive operators without cultural vetting.

Expected.Present pattern: Some cultural assessment done, but surface-level.
Expected.Signals: Different risk tolerance or communication norms.

Excellent.Present pattern: Deep evaluation of cultural fit before funding.
Excellent.Edge condition: You prioritize culture fit as highly as capital terms.
Excellent.Future effect: Culture grows stronger with each raise.

Transcendent.Edge condition: You refuse capital that shifts cultural norms.

Guiding Questions: How does this funder work with portfolio companies?
Do their values align with ours?
Would they thrive in our cultural environment?

Themes.Name: Understanding Expectations on Returns and Timeline
Themes.Purpose of This Theme: To clarify the funder’s expectations for financial returns and timing.
Themes.Why This Matters: Misaligned expectations create pressure that can distort decisions.

Poor.Present pattern: You accept funding without understanding return expectations.
Poor.Edge condition: You avoid talking about return timelines.

Expected.Present pattern: Some discussion of returns, but vague timelines.

Excellent.Present pattern: Clear agreement on realistic return and timeline.
Excellent.Edge condition: You negotiate timelines based on reality.

Transcendent.Edge condition: You resist timelines that distort build.
Transcendent.Future effect: Pace and payoff align with integrity.

Guiding Questions: What return does this funder expect?
How does that align with our growth rhythm?

Themes.Name: Evaluating Non-Capital Value
Themes.Purpose of This Theme: To assess the strategic, operational, or network value beyond money that a funder brings.
Themes.Why This Matters: Capital is important, but additional value can accelerate success—or lack of it can slow you down.

Poor.Present pattern: Decision is based on capital only.
Poor.Signals: Funder absent in value creation beyond money.
Poor.Example moves: Not asking about introductions or expertise.

Expected.Edge condition: You rely on capital to solve all challenges.

Excellent.Present pattern: Deliberate evaluation of funder’s added value.
Excellent.Edge condition: You factor non-capital value into selection.

Transcendent.Present pattern: Non-capital value is weighted equally with capital.
Transcendent.Signals: Funder is a true partner in success.
Transcendent.Edge condition: You never choose based on money alone.
Transcendent.Example moves: Cultural habit of valuing contribution over cheque size.

Guiding Questions: What value does this funder bring beyond capital?
How will that value shape our next phase?
Would we want them involved if no money was exchanged?

Themes.Name: Protecting Autonomy and Governance
Themes.Purpose of This Theme: To safeguard decision-making power and governance integrity when accepting funding.
Themes.Why This Matters: Even aligned funders can unintentionally erode autonomy through governance structures.

Poor.Present pattern: Governance terms are accepted without review.

Expected.Present pattern: Some governance review, but concessions made without safeguards.
Expected.Edge condition: You accept governance terms to secure deal.

Transcendent.Signals: No risk of hostile governance shifts.
Transcendent.Edge condition: You refuse deals that weaken governance.
Transcendent.Example moves: Cultural mantra of safeguarding decision rights.

Guiding Questions: What governance terms protect our autonomy?
Where are we willing to share control?

Completion Prompts: Identify one funder whose values align with your strategic goals.
Name one cultural signal that indicates a strong funder fit.
Choose one governance term to prioritize in your next negotiation.

Algorithm.Description: Matches funder profiles with strategic and cultural criteria (funder fit matching).

Unit Economics as a Living Compass
